results.notes:
Code: Bot_1096/2017_DSC9621

Habitat: mountain pasture; slightly inclined terrain, southeast aspect; colluvial/glacial, calcareous ground; full sun, dry place; elevation 575 m (1.900 feet); average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: a pile of partly rotten stump of Picea abies, mostly still in bark.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, right bank of river Soča; between villages Soča and Trenta; near Trenta 2 farm house, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: Average diameter of seven aethalia found was somewhat small (AVG = 4.5 mm, SD = 0.6 mm) compared to data from literature (the smallest had only 2.2 mm in diameter); however all other macroscopic traits fit well to Lycogala epidendrum species descriptions. Microscopically spore dimensions, their shape and reticulated surface, all fit to this species. Also pseudocapillitium diameter, its surface with conspicuous transverse faults and its club shaped free ends fit well. Spore mass grayish with pink tint.

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Sony ILCE6000 / Carl Zeiss Vario-Tessar E 16-70mm F4

results.notes:
Habitat: mixed conifer woods (pines, Douglas-fir, Incense Cedar)
Cap appearance variable, with margins developing striations. Pileus color red to purplish-rosy, creamy off-white to dull pale yellow at center, the paler area varying in size and shape.
Stipe clean white. Gill forking occasional, becoming light yellow to light brownish yellow. Cap peeling easily, almost to halfway to center.
Spores pale ochre-yellow/light straw-color, 7-8×8-9 micros, round and usually with a protuberance. Warts isolated, of medium density, and relatively even spacing.
Scent weak, sweet and “warm”, sort of like gingerbread cookies
Taste peppery, but not burning hot, and calming down after the first few seconds.

results.notes:
In Blue Oak Woodland, on bark of Quercus douglasii, along the Jim Green Trail.

Thallus barely evident, dark grey, scurfy (blastidiate?), K-, C-, KC-. Apothecia dispersed, sessile, plane rarely becoming convex, with a black epruinose disk and lighter thalline margin hardly raised, containing algae. Epihymenium dark brown, hymenium hyaline, hypothecium hyaline. Paraphyses caps dark.

Spores 8/ascus, 1-septate, broadly ellipsoid to ellipsoid, some with acute apices, at times bean shaped, brown in maturity with a dark septum, septum generally slightly swollen, showing a slight torus at maturity, spore walls seem to remain thick, with rounded lumina, somewhat angular when immature. Average size: 19.5×7.4 (n=4).

Seems to be something close to R. santa-monicae or maybe even R. poeltiana.

results.notes:
Spotted in Gordon County, (Northwest) Georgia, US. Growing under the bark of a large rotting willow oak log. Light pink to peach crust fungus (with white edges in younger areas of specimen) and small, distinctive pores. More mature areas are very lumpy (pores are often stretched). Some of the edges have turned a shade of violet. A gray/brown to white-capped shelf fungus with a bright white pore surface is growing atop (?) this specimen.

I was thinking this looked a lot like Peniophora of some sort, but I’m unsure! Any ID help is much appreciated!

results.notes:
I found these on the lichen-and-algae-covered trunk of a small fallen tree in almost primairy forest in Suriname, at an altitude of close to 600 masl. They have a hard outside and are firmly attached to the trunk, and from memory they were about 6mm in height. In the second photo a specimen which I forcefully broke off.

My original guess was that these were ootheca (egg-cases) of some insect (with some of the partially developed young showing inside). Someone else then suggested the family Xylariaceae. So what is the pale-green substance? Future spores?

results.notes: Found this brain-like jelly on an icy, decomposing log in pine-dominated area of Mohonk Mountain House. I don’t know the species of the log. The jelly (if that’s what it is) was growing next to what I believe were Rosellinia. There were small blobs of the jelly growing directly on some of the Rosellinia, so I’m left wondering whether it is a parasite or at least facultatively so. I’ve looked at all my guidebooks and online and haven’t been comfortable IDing it. I’d be grateful for any thoughts.

Thallus of continuous, white, rounded verrucae, cortex K+? dingy light yellow?, C+R. Apothecia common, crowded, with a thick prominent thalline margin, disk pale orange, epruinose, C+R, margin cortex K+Yish, C+R. Medulla C? (got C+R, but maybe there was some cortex material left). Cortex UV-. Algae thick in exciple and beneath apothecia.

O. subpallescens is the only species I ever seem to collect around here, but I’m sure there are others. One of these days I’ll make a concerted effort on this genus.

results.notes:
plants around: live oak, black oak, manzanitas, ponderosa pine
strong farinaceous odor
Ochraceous brown spores that were cortinarius-like (almond shape, barely rough), but cannot find any fitting species with this strong tricholoma-like mealy/farinaceous odor, etc.
Specimen photos after a week are also attached. Stipe was easy to split lengthwise, but difficult to cut across, not tearing cleanly. Note fine cap fibrils. See photos.
The base of the stem, not pictured, was not enlarged, but otherwise it was similar to some phlegmaciums. Cortina thin, but extensive. The cap color became slightly more orange-brown when old. Did not do a KOH reaction before it had to be discarded, unfortunately.
Likely undescribed (?)

results.notes:
unscented
mixed oak/madrone/pine woods
Bright white gills turn creamy yellow with pale yellow spore print
Taste very mild (no hint of being acrid), but not too good. The aftertaste lingers a LONG time.
The stipe shows a very faint brownish gray bruising that is very slow to develop.
After a week, dried one began to have a weak smell, not overly fishy or unpleasant, but slightly shrimpy perhaps and not so great. It can take a few whiffs to notice.
The bright violet cap becomes darker toward the center and with age.
Stipe is solid, with a wonderful soft but firm texture. Cuts very cleanly and easily. The inside is off- white, kind of a very pale grayish brown. Gills also break cleanly. Flesh white and can show purplish marks as the cap is peeled or cut. The rosy marking on the stipe never reached the apex. Thick, proportionately short and cylindrical stipe. Cuticle peels easily, at least to a third of the length to the center. Cap width about 10.4 cm, stipe width about 2.5 cm near the halfway point. Cap with unstriated margin.
Photos of specimen taken after one week

The appearance reminds me of hygrophoropsis aurantiaca a bit, but with almost no stipe. It seems unlikely to me, but I have not found anything better yet, so using that as a placeholder. The cap seems to be fully developed for any of the local lentinellus, tapinellus, etc, but I don’t know. I hope it is distinctive enough that someone can put a name to it. I didn’t take a specimen.

results.notes:
Growing among leaf litter near Quercus spp., Pinus strobus, Tsuga canadensis, Fagus grandifolia, Carpinus caroliniana, Betula alleghaniensis and Acer spp. Odor not distinctive. Pileipellis a cutis with pale brown intracellular pigment. Clamps present in the pileipellis, stipe and lamellar trama. Caulocystidia scattered, hyaline and cylindrical to utriform. Lamellar trama subregular. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia scattered, hyaline, thin-walled, smooth and ellipsoid to subglobose to obovoid to broadly clavate. Cheilocystidia measurements: (16.9) 19.7 – 33.4 (37.5) × (8.7) 11.2 – 23.1 (23.8) µm; Q = (1) 1.2 – 2 (2.4); N = 30; Me = 24.8 × 15.9 µm; Qe = 1.6. Basidia clavate and 4-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: 31.7 – 40 (40.1) × (9.5) 10.4 – 11.8 (13) µm; Q = (2.4) 2.8 – 3.5 (4.2); N = 9; Me = 35.4 × 11.1 µm; Qe = 3.2. Spores angular, pink in mass and 5 to 7-sided. Spore measurements: (6.9) 7.8 – 9.6 (9.8) × (5.9) 6.1 – 7.1 (7.5) µm; Q = (1.1) 1.2 – 1.4 (1.6); N = 30; Me = 8.6 × 6.7 µm; Qe = 1.3

Mirrored on iNaturalist at https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/11195063

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1046/2017_DSC7333

Habitat: : mountain scree slope, southeast aspect; open, sunny, dry place; calcareous ground; exposed to direct rain; elevation 680 m; average temperature 6-8 deg C, average precipitations ~3.000 mm/year; alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: dead, rotten trunk of Fagus sylvatica lying on ground.

Place: Lower Trenta valley; between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča near lower hunter’s trail from Na Melu place to Lemovlje, below Na skalah settlement, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: This ascomycete remains a secret for me. It appears to have perithecioid ascomata with occasionally papillate apex, cellular pseudoparaphyses, bitunicate (hope so) and clavate/cylindrical 8-spore asci, ascospores with pigmentation and several septa and peridium composed of a few layers of cells. Thus it possibly belongs to fungi order Pleosporales Luttr. ex M.E. Barr. This order comprises tens of families and thousands of species. I searched for species, which stain decaying wood reddish/purplish. I browsed through short descriptions of about 160 species studied in the paper of Zhang et al. (2009) (Table:1). Several species, which stain substratum reddish, are cited, but none fits to this observation. It is also possible that my assumption about Pleosporales is completely wrong and this find is something totally different. Hard to manage is also the fact that the traditional taxonomy based exclusively on morphology has been overturned drastically by recent molecular studies. Hense proper naming of species (even genera and families) is confusing for an amateur. Unfortunately, there was no response from AscoFrance forum either. Any help would be much appreciated.

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Sony a6000 / Carl Zeiss Vario-Tessar E 16-70mm/ f4

results.notes:
See a video of a specimen collected in Coffee County, Georgia at https://youtu.be/pOa2ECym254 .
A video of the current specimen is at https://youtu.be/gClHXFttrAI .

Spores strongly amyloid (a feature of Russulales); subglobose to broadly ellipsoid, slightly ornamented, 2.49×2.06 | 2.92×2.35 | 2.96×2.13 (with D. Jean Lodge). This specimen was originally located by Sam Landes.

I have found what appears to be the same fungus five times in three Georgia counties – four times in the last two months of 2017, three of those in disparate locations in the woods behind my house. I have found the fungus once on white oak (this observation), three times on pine (two of those loblolly, the other too degraded to be sure). I have added all 5 observations to MO (SEE LIST BELOW). MycoPortal lists 8 observations in 5 states between 1913 and 2013, including one on Mushroom Observer. Jacob Kalichman recently added one (304291) from Tennessee.

Interestingly, the only observation before 2015 that mentions the striking elastic nature of the fungus was the one posted on Mushroom Observer in 2013 (153146) by V. Parker in North Carolina: “Fruit body is flexible and pulls apart like gum or putty.” I cannot find any other mention of elastic polypores anywhere on google. Yet it is so striking in the field!

Another interesting feature of the fungus is the way it permeates the entire log, making much of it so soft and sponge-like that one can easily dig in the wood with fingers. When you pull bits of wood apart you see white mycelial strands stretching – albeit on a smaller scale than the fruiting body.

COLLECTIONS BY BILL SHEEHAN

results.notes:
Specimen collected and photographed by Jesse Buechter.
Herbarium sample held by Stephen Russell.
Field guides typically list it as having no odor, and most people agree. Some people report light, sweet odor. As it turns out, it’s actually the stinkiest mushroom I’ve ever come across, but only SOME people can smell it! It’s so strong I can smell it from several feet away and through a sealed ziplock baggie.
I had a sample and 20 willing, perhaps reluctant, participants all smell the same sample. Of them, only myself and one little boy could smell it. It is a pungent, minty, chemically smell, reminiscent of camphor. (The little boy described it as peppermint.) It’s so strong I can smell it from several feet away and through a sealed ziplock baggie. Since then, I regularly poll people when they find it, and have had several smaller groups of people all sniff the same sample. Only about 1 out of 20 seem to be able to detect the odor.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_386/2009-5213

Habitat: mountain mixed wood, Fagus sylvatica, Picea abies, Fraxinus ornus, Ostrya carpinifolia dominant trees; slightly inclined terrain, southeast aspect; relatively dry and warm place; colluvial, calcareous ground; in shade; elevation 575 m (1.900 feet); average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: dead, still standing trunk of Fagus sylvatica, mostly still in bark.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, right bank of river Soča; between villages Soča and Trenta; near the trail form Trenta 2b cottage to Strgulc abandoned farm house, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Totally hidden behind the bark of a dead Fagus sylvatica tree this find was a surprise. I still don’t know what inspired me to peel off a small piece of the bark what revealed the tiny fruitbodies. The very young pilei were recognized because several half-decayed pilei of the same species were present on the same trunk. The trunk was also infected by Fomes fomentarius, which commonly grow together with Oudemansiella mucida. Also very slimy pilei speak in favor of this determination.

An interesting observation: Ref.5., p 491 states that young fruitbodies do not develop huts in no light conditions. This seems not the case with this find. All fruitbodies (even the smallest ones only 2 – 3 mm tall) had huts in spite of the fact that they grew in total darkness.

The largest fruitbody was 20 mm tall and the hut had 4 mm in diameter the smallest one was 3.1 mm tall and the hut had 0.8 mm in diameter. Smell almost none, taste mild, indistinctive; no spores have been found.

Ref.:
(1) M. Bon, Parey’s Buch der Pilze, Kosmos (2005), p 170.
(2) R.M.Daehncke, 1200 Pilze in Farbfotos, AT Verlag (2009), p 335.
(3) S. Buczacki, Collins Fungi Guide, Collins (2012), p 200.
(4) J. Breitenbach, F. Kraenzlin, Eds., Fungi of Switzerland, Vol.3. Verlag Mykologia (1991), p 308.
(5) G.J. Krieglsteiner (Hrsg.), Die Grosspilze Baden-Württembergs, Band 3., Ulmer (2001), p 490.

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

Fun video of spore release was also obtained
Lycogala spp from encyclopedia of life:
Conicum- oddly shaped, dark- scaled aethalia
Confusum- also darker scaled aethalia, probably doesn’t occur here, could be similar (little information)
Exiguum- spore mass never pink
Flavofuscum- very distinct, with odd gray phase and scaleless. It also has a buffier spore mass and smaller spores
Fuscoviolaceum- spores tend to be just slightly larger and are more heavily reticulated. Cortex with irregularly shaped vesicles filled with yellow fluid (not observed). Apparently very rare.
Terrestrial/Epidendrum (synonymous)- abundant, cosmopolitan sp, fits characters at different stages, imo. Spores same size as observation.

results.notes:
On siliceous rock outcropping along a riparian corridor.

Thallus is white, consisting of contiguous, rimose, pruinose, convex areoles that are K-. Pycnidia are common. Apothecia locally common, but can be absent over large areas. Disk black, rarely lightly pruinose. Epihymenium with green tints. IKI (Lugol’s): hymenium IKI+blue turning red. Exciple never turning blue, just yellowish red. Hypothecium slowly blue the completely turning red.

Spores large, broadly ellipsoid, hyaline. Measurements and #/ascus to come. Conidia measurements coming too.

I’m certain these are within Tricholomataceae but they are too large and colorful to be lyophyllum, the gills are too thinly-spaced and blade-like to be laccaria, the presence of sn annulus eliminates clitocybe, and the color + annulus eliminate tricholoma…

results.notes:
Code: Bot_323/2009_DSC6432

Habitat: rocks of a dirt road scarp; humid and shady place; mixed forest and grassland around, no insolation during winter months; often wet place; north aspect; about 1.5 mm above the road level; exposed to direct rain; precipitations ~3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 400 m (1.300 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: on Gyalecta sp. lichen; vertical, hard, calcareous rock surface.

Place: Bovec basin, southeast of village Čezsoča, dirt road side leading to former ski lifts, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: Substratum, habitat and habit correspond well to Opegrapha rupestris. It is the only lichen of this genus which grows on calcareous rock in most cases parasitizing other crustose lichens, usually a species of Verrucariaceae, but also other lichens. Backwards analysis (backwards because of the lack of microscopic data) of the keys published in Ref.: 1, 3 and 4 show no conflicts. Ref.: 5 states several finds of Opegrapha rupestris in Slovenia, however, no finds are included in Boletus Informaticus Database (Ref.: 6). Unfortunately no chemical test and microscopy have been done. Therefore the determination remains questionable.

Nikon D70 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8
